text: Something happened at work today. Something good. I was given admin privileges on my local machine. I feel like I won some sort of epic battle and saved a small village and instead of taking the peoples gifts I told them to treat me as an equal and that I would return sometime soon after my next adventure.

text:
I’ve never understood this whole non-admin permissions for employees thing.

EDIT: By that I mean, I understand it, I don’t agree with it and it doesn’t make any sense.

text: no admin access is a dealbreaker for me

text: my last position I had to do desperate things to get stuff done. But at my new one I can just... install VStudio and Rust, and whatever else

text: this has me terrified of working in industry.. What if my employer forces me to use python? or worse,,,, windows ???

elements.text: this has me terrified of working in industry.. What if my employer forces me to use python? or worse,,,, windows ???

text:
> this has me terrified of working in industry.. What if my employer forces me to use python? or worse,,,, windows ???
Unfortunately that's how most non-software companies work. You don't get a choice, only what IT is willing to support. And anything that isn't owned by a company is viewed with suspicion.
Corporate support is key, so even if you can get Linux it'll be Red Hat and nothing else. And don't dream of BYOD (which I wouldn't want anyway in my company. Our laptops are so full of crap due to the ton of "security" software they require to connect to the intranet they've become sluggish to use, I would never allow a computer I bought with my own money to be mistreated like that). We have a BYOD scheme for mobile phones, but to make it work you have to give the company the right to reset your phone to factory settings and erase every file in its memory without even warning you in advance!

Corporate support is key, so even if you can get Linux it'll be Red Hat and nothing else. And don't dream of BYOD (which I wouldn't want anyway in my company. Our laptops are so full of crap due to the ton of "security" software they require to connect to the intranet they've become sluggish to use, I would never allow a computer I bought with my own money to be mistreated like that). We have a BYOD scheme for mobile phones, but to make it work you have to give the company the right to reset your phone to factory settings and erase every file in its memory without even warning you in advance!
